data.title: Dandy Dust (1998)
data.meta_description: Dust, a split-personality cyborg of fluid gender, zooms through time and space in search of his/her own memories and a sense of understanding. S/he travels from the Planet of White Dust where war is constant, to the Planet of Blood and Swelling, a hybrid of his/her father’s body.
data.text:
Rigid gender norms push those of us who don't fit into them. Often that push is small, a nudge here or there, a little rebellion. Wearing pants to this, earrings to that, makeup here, not cooking this, not doing that job, not taking that shit. Sometimes, it's a bigger push, and those of us far outside the rigid norms suffer for it. Depression and anxiety and the trauma of the closet can take hold. Some of us break free to varying degrees. We find ourselves outside these norms, we find ourselves in different norms or in completely deconstructed realms. Some, perhaps, take it to extremes I wouldn't personally go to but I respect it. Some find a complete rejection of…

Much of the time 'transgressive' is thoughtlessly tacked onto the category of queer cinema as a last minute justification, as if defending it from the now-frequent (and idiotic) charge by popular Twitter criticism that a director is guilty of putting his or her fetishes on screen -- like that's a bad thing anyway. Dandy Dust is actually transgressive. A clique of creative European perverts got together and figured out how to assault the senses through as many mediums as possible on a prop budget of around 50 dollars: claymation, stop-motion miniatures, crude video editor effects, bursts of cacaphonous industrial noise. But all this obnoxiousness delivers a joyous message: join us and shed your shame, your self-awareness, your insistence on logic…
